perturbation.original_text: 1.26 "Commercially Reasonable Efforts" means: (a) with respect to the efforts to be expended, or considerations to be undertaken, by a Party or its Affiliate with respect to any objective, activity or decision to be undertaken hereunder, reasonable, good faith efforts to accomplish such objective, activity or decision as such Party would normally use to accomplish a similar objective, activity or decision under similar circumstances; and (b) with respect to Development and Commercialization of any Licensed Product for any indication by a Party, efforts and resources consistent with those efforts and resources commonly used by a similarly situated biotechnology company with respect to a product owned by it or to which it has similar rights, which product is at a similar stage in its development or product life and is of similar market potential taking into account (i) the patent and other proprietary position of the Licensed Product and (ii) the anticipated profitability of the Licensed Product.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.26 "Commercially Reasonable Efforts" means: (a) with respect to the efforts to be expended, or considerations to be undertaken, by a Party or its Affiliate with respect to any objective, activity or decision to be undertaken hereunder, good faith efforts to accomplish such objective, activity or decision.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the specific section (b) on how to measure efforts and resources for Development and Commercialization, the definition becomes vague. This introduces uncertainty in enforcement, particularly concerning the level of investment and dedication required from Vyera. Later sections depend on this full definition, making it an in-text contradiction because the standard is undefined.

perturbation.original_text: 5.5 Decisions that are not Reserved. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Article 5 or any other section of this Agreement: (a) the Minimum Requirements may not be modified, amended or otherwise changed without the written consent of CytoDyn, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed; and [***].
perturbation.changed_text: 5.5 Decisions that are not Reserved. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Article 5 or any other section of this Agreement: (a) the Minimum Requirements may not be modified, amended or otherwise changed without the written consent of CytoDyn.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase 'such consent not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed', CytoDyn now has absolute discretion over modifying the Minimum Requirements. This contradicts the general spirit of the agreement, which expects reasonable behavior. A later section uses this condition.

perturbation.original_text: 12.4 Reserved Disputes. Certain disputes that are specifically defined below shall be finally decided by the executive officer of one of the Parties ("Reserved Disputes"). In such cases, the executive officer of that Party shall make his or her decision with regard to the Reserved Dispute within twenty (20) days of its referral and such decision shall be final and binding and shall not be subject to Section 12.3. Reserved Disputes shall not include disputes with respect to the interpretation, breach, termination or invalidity of this Agreement. [***]
perturbation.changed_text: 12.4 Reserved Disputes. Certain disputes that are specifically defined below shall be finally decided by the executive officer of one of the Parties ("Reserved Disputes"). In such cases, the executive officer of that Party shall make his or her decision with regard to the Reserved Dispute within twenty (20) days of its referral and such decision shall be final and binding and shall not be subject to Section 12.3. Reserved Disputes shall not include disputes with respect to the interpretation, breach, termination or invalidity of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the specific items that constitute a reserved dispute, the contract now provides that certain disputes will be decided by an executive officer, but lacks any guidance as to which ones. This makes the scope of the executive officer's power undefined and creates enforcement uncertainty.
